Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating 'electricity-generating' Microbial Communities for Enhanced Conversion of Biomass to Hydrogen
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study how 'electricity-generating' microbial communities work together to convert biomass streams into energy products. The researcher will use sequencing techniques to investigate the microbial community?' response to certain operational conditions, and will be combined with other collected data to effectively characterize it. This project will be conducted at the Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology (JAMSTEC) under the mentorship of Dr. Shunichi Ishii, who is an expert in studying microbial communities with a developed pipeline for sequencing analysis. The resulting data will provide the foundation for understanding microbial community structure and function, and how to utilize process conditions to maintain optimal performance. The broader implications for this research stretch to all bioenergy technologies, where we are striving to demonstrate the advantages of integrated systems for fuel and chemical production.

The overall goal of the proposed research is utilize modern metagenomics and transcriptomics techniques as part of a systems biology approach for investigating bioelectrochemical systems to uncover the effects of process parameters and biomass-derived streams on community dynamics. This project will be conducted at the Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology (JAMSTEC) under the mentorship of Dr. Shunichi Ishii, who is an expert in studying microbial communities with a developed pipeline for sequencing analysis. The resulting data will provide the basis for developing process parameters as a management tool for directing and engineering optimal community structure, metabolic capacity, and electrochemical performance in a bioelectrochemical systems. Furthermore, the broader implications for this research stretch to all bioenergy technologies, where we are striving to demonstrate the advantages of integrated systems for fuel and chemical production.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this work was to characterize a high-performing microbial community degrading waste biomass via microbial electrolysis. To do so, the host Dr. Shunichi Ishii, provided training on the steps involved in raw DNA sequence assembly, and creation of 'bins' from which individual microbes can be identified. Additional steps learned involved the annotation of the DNA sequences to identify genes present within the community. These techniques were then successfully applied to analyze genomic data from a microbial community enriched to convert a biomass-derived stream in a micorbial electrolysis cell. The analysis techniques resulted in the generation of more than 20 high-quality genomes from the microbial community. The analysis also allowed for the identification of genes involved in biomass degradation as well as electron transfer in potentially novel microbes. The results and data are still being processed with a manuscript in preparation. The results contribute to expanding our understanding how microbial communities within bioelectrochemical systems can effectively convert biomass, and demonstrates the potential of this technology to generate renewable energy from waste streams. Additionally, the microbial characterizations related to interactions between community members and genes involved in degradation can have broader impacts for understanding how natural communities may work in the subsurface to degrade organic content and how these abilities can be harvested for bioenergy generation.


Last Modified: 06/07/2017
Modified by: Alex J Lewis

To do so, the host Dr. Shunichi Ishii, provided training on the steps involved in raw DNA sequence assembly, and creation of 'bins' from which individual microbes can be identified. Additional steps learned involved the annotation of the DNA sequences to identify genes present within the community. These techniques were then successfully applied to analyze genomic data from a microbial community enriched to convert a biomass-derived stream in a micorbial electrolysis cell. The analysis techniques resulted in the generation of more than 20 high-quality genomes from the microbial community. The analysis also allowed for the identification of genes involved in biomass degradation as well as electron transfer in potentially novel microbes. The results and data are still being processed with a manuscript in preparation. The results contribute to expanding our understanding how microbial communities within bioelectrochemical systems can effectively convert biomass, and demonstrates the potential of this technology to generate renewable energy from waste streams. Additionally, the microbial characterizations related to interactions between community members and genes involved in degradation can have broader impacts for understanding how natural communities may work in the subsurface to degrade organic content and how these abilities can be harvested for bioenergy generation.
